title: Particle Motion with Eulers Method and Taylor Poly

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds.” The heading for row 2 is “x prime of t, in feet per second.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. x prime of t is 2.4. Column 2. t is 6. x prime of t is negative 1.4. Column 3. t is 12. x prime of t is 4.0. Column 4. t is 18. x prime of t is 5.4. Column 5. t is 24. x prime of t is 6.2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="false" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per second)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>2.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>1.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> The position of a particle moving along a straight line is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the table above. The position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="x of 0 equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with two subintervals of equal length and values from the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 24, of, x prime of t, dt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds.” The heading for row 2 is “x prime of t, in feet per second.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. x prime of t is 2.4. Column 2. t is 6. x prime of t is negative 1.4. Column 3. t is 12. x prime of t is 4.0. Column 4. t is 18. x prime of t is 5.4. Column 5. t is 24. x prime of t is 6.2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalcolumns="false" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>18</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>24</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per second)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>2.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>1.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6.2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> The position of a particle moving along a straight line is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="x prime of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, are shown in the table above. The position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="x of 0 equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with two subintervals of equal length and values from the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 24, of, x prime of t, dt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(b) Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 24, of, x prime of t, dt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>24</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) Must there be a time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than t, less than 24" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, when the velocity of the particle is zero? Justify your answer.

(d) Use Euler’s method, starting at <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with two steps of equal size, to approximate the position of the particle at time <math alttext="t equals 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) It is known that <math alttext="x double prime of 0, equals negative 6.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6.8</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) Let <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function such that the sixth derivative of <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with respect to <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="open parenthesis, t plus 5, close parenthesis, raised to the seventh power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write the sixth-degree term of the sixth-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="t equals negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
